animalOfTheDay.name: wasp
facts: Parasitoid wasps lay eggs in hosts; larvae eat prey alive while avoiding vital organs.
Fig wasps co-evolved with figs – each fig species has its own wasp pollinator.
Wasps produce paper by chewing wood fibers mixed with saliva.
Mud daubers build tubular nests with paralyzed spiders as living food for larvae.

calendar.name: vicuna
facts: Vicuñas spit foul-smelling cud at competitors during disputes.
They have lower incisor teeth that grow continuously like rodents.
Inca royalty wore vicuña robes; illegal poaching still threatens populations.
Vicuñas produce the finest wool – fibers measure 12 micrometers (human hair: 75).

calendar.name: viper
facts: Vipers have heat-sensing pits detecting temperature changes as small as 0.003°C.
Their hinged fangs fold against the roof of mouth when not striking.
Gaboon vipers have longest fangs (2 inches) and highest venom yield.
Horned vipers in deserts move via sidewinding to avoid hot sand.

calendar.name: vulture
facts: They have an excellent sense of smell.
Vultures are scavenging birds of prey.
Vultures play a crucial role in ecosystems by cleaning up carcasses.
They are known for their bald heads, which help keep them clean while feeding.

calendar.name: wallaby
facts: Rock wallabies scale cliffs using textured soles and tail balancing.
Wallabies cool by licking forearms; saliva evaporation lowers blood temperature.
They practice embryonic diapause; pausing development until environmental conditions improve.
Wallabies hop efficiently – energy use doesn't increase with speed.

calendar.name: walrus
facts: They are social animals and live in large herds.
Walruses use their tusks to haul themselves onto ice and to forage for food.
They are found in Arctic waters.
Walruses are large marine mammals known for their prominent tusks.

calendar.name: warthog
facts: Warthogs kneel on calloused wrists to graze low vegetation.
They reverse into burrows – tusks facing outward to deter predators.
Warthogs have facial 'warts' that protect eyes during fights.
Birds like mongooses remove ticks from warthogs during grooming sessions.

calendar.name: wasp
facts: Fig wasps co-evolved with figs – each fig species has its own wasp pollinator.
Wasps produce paper by chewing wood fibers mixed with saliva.
Parasitoid wasps lay eggs in hosts; larvae eat prey alive while avoiding vital organs.
Mud daubers build tubular nests with paralyzed spiders as living food for larvae.

randomAnimals.name: lamb
facts: They form strong social bonds and can become stressed when separated from their flock.
Lambs can recognize their mother's voice within a few hours of being born.
Lambs are born with a full set of milk teeth that are replaced by adult teeth as they grow.
They can stand and walk within an hour of being born.

randomAnimals.name: black bear
facts: They have color vision and can see better than humans.
They can run up to 30 mph and are excellent climbers and swimmers.
Cubs are born the size of hamsters and weigh less than a pound.
Black bears aren't always black - they can be brown, cinnamon, or even blonde.

randomAnimals.name: civet
facts: Civets are cat-like mammals from Africa and Asia, known for their ability to secrete a musky scent, used in perfumery.
Most species are nocturnal and arboreal, although some are more terrestrial.
Kopi Luwak coffee, one of the most expensive coffees in the world, is produced from beans that have been digested and excreted by civets.
They are omnivorous, eating fruits, insects, small mammals, and birds.
